title: Local market disconnected from global reality: BP
text:
Considering most of the gas in production or is slated for production lies in Queensland’s north, and most of the demand is in Sydney and Melbourne, getting it to market via pipeline or through liquefication (via an LNG inmport terminal) is a “line-ball” decision.

“A pipeline would be very expensive especially to build because the geographic distances are so great. Taking this into account, you could make the argument that the process of liquefication is actually cheaper than a pipeline,” Mr Boey said.

Mr Boey disagreed Australia was short of gas because it’s obvious there is a lot of gas on the east coast.

“There is gas in place but it’s the policy and commercial framework that sits on top of the gas reserves that presents them from being commercialised at scale which causes the supply crunches.

“We need a way to liberate supply from the ground because at the moment there’s an artificial constraint at the front end which causes some of the effects we’re now seeing,” he said.

A case in point is at Narrabri in western NSW, which is still to be developed despite growing support from the local community and government.

Santos head of gas commercialisation Jane Norman was confident the project will get through the approval process and once in production, it will only supply the domestic market.

“It has the potential to supply up to half of the state’s gas needs, so it’s a very important development.

While the east coast market struggles with supply issues and high prices, Western Australia’s Energy Transition Strategy is designed to ensure reliable and affordable energy into the future is built on abundant natural gas supplies.

Energy WA’s assistant executive director, Kate Ryan, said the state’s consumers use more natural gas than any other state, despite making up only 10 per cent of the nation’s population.

She said gas is designed to be more flexible in WA and this is ensured through the state’s reservation policy where the experience on the ground has been very positive.

Ms Ryan said with a lot of new LNG having been developed over the last decade in WA, there has been a tightening in the market but nothing like what the eastern states have experienced.

“How much of this can be attributed to the state’s domestic gas reservation policy is unknown,” Ms Ryan said.
description: The tyranny of distance melded with policy inertia on production driving many of the problems in eastern Australia's gas market set it apart from the rest of the world.
